Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Testing a Mechanism for the Productivity-Beta Diversity Relationship in Plants
Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual merit: Globally, the diversity of plants and animals is highest in regions where rainfall and solar energy are abundant, which yields high rates of carbon capture via photosynthesis termed primary productivity. This project will analyze a previously unexamined aspect of this pattern, namely, how productivity affects the degree to which plants are specialized on different soils, which can drive the variation in species composition among different locations. In productive climates, this project will test the hypothesis that plant communities on different soils will be highly distinct because intensified competition leads to narrower soil niches, whereas in colder or more arid climates less distinctiveness of plant communities across soil boundaries is predicted. These predictions will be tested by comparing plant communities on chemically unusual soils such as serpentine, limestone, and dolomite, to those on nearby normal soils, across gradients of high to low rainfall in California and the Ozarks. To better understand the mechanisms for the observed patterns, experimental manipulations of rainfall and plant competition in neighboring serpentine and non-serpentine plant communities in California will be conducted. This research is important because plant species and communities endemic to particular soils are important contributors to global botanical diversity. Our results will help understand how climate controls plant diversity, plant community composition, and the degree to which plant communities are affected by biological invasions.

Broader impacts: A graduate student from an underrepresented group and several undergraduates will be trained with this award. Data will be made available to researchers, agency scientists, and nonprofit environmental groups through the data archives of the Knowledge Network for Biocomplexity (knb.ecoinformatics.org) and the UC Natural Reserve System Data Registry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

Maintaining sustainable ecosystems into the future relies on a comprehensive understanding of how natural environmental factors and human-mediated management strategies affect biological diversity. Some of the world’s most diverse and unique plant communities are found in areas with unusual soils. Understanding what factors contribute to these highly diverse and unique communities is not only an important basic ecological question but also is critical for effectively managing these important ecosystems. In this project, we evaluated the impact of environmental conditions and management actions at both local sites and across large landscapes using two unique soil ecosystems – serpentine soil outcrops in California and Oregon, and dolomite soil glades in the Missouri and Arkansas Ozarks.

In California and Oregon, we sampled plant communities from 96 pairs of sites on serpentine and non-serpentine soils across a 1200-km latitudinal gradient. We found that more favorable climates with higher precipitation led to greater distinctiveness of the diversity of plants found on harsh serpentine soils relative to nearby plant communities found on more benign soils. Overall, we found that more productive climates yield higher diversity of species and functions within sites and higher turnover of species among sites. In the Ozark dolomite glades, we also found significant turnover in species across soil types.

Using an experiment, we found that low-fertility habitats such as those on harsh serpentine soils, may be slow to respond to changes in precipitation when compared to communities on more fertile soils (non-serpentine). This corroborated results from a second, long-term experiment that showed that communities on harsh serpentine soils were more stable over time, responding less dramatically to wet and dry years, than communities on more benign soils. One of the major reasons for this increase in community stability was that serpentine plant species have stress-tolerant characteristics (e.g., thick leaves) compared to their non-serpentine counterparts, allowing greater survival. More broadly, we found that while special soils may contain species that are able to persist locally, these species may be unable to move to new sites. This suggests that promoting the resilience of special soil communities will require managing for large and connected habitats at a landscape scale.

Our findings from dolomite glades in the Missouri and Arkansas Ozarks similarly found that landscape connectivity was a significant predictor of the diversity of specialist, but not generalist species. In addition, habitats that were small or isolated at the landscape scale were comprised of plant species with poorer dispersal abilities. Both of these findings suggest that specialist species rely more heavily on the configuration of habitat and are poorer dispersers relative to their generalist counterparts.

One factor that may be affecting the amount and arrangement of open dolomite glade grassland habitat is the impact of changing disturbance regimes. Historically, these ecosystems were maintained by frequent, low-intensity fires. Today, many sites have not been burned for decades while others are maintained using prescribed fire management. Using aerial imagery from the past and present, we found that woody vegetation has significantly encroached glades over time. Using prescribed fire management reduces encroachment overall and especially for some species, however, it has not been able to reverse the impact of previous decades of encroachment.
